questions.text: Which one of the following vessels supplies Broca's area (essential for the production of language)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Broca's area, which is essential for motor aspects of speech production, lies in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere and is supplied by the superior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

  • It is perfused by the superior cortical branches of the MCA, which emerge from the lateral (sylvian) fissure and supply much of the lateral surface of the frontal lobe.

Superior branches of MCA supply these key functional areas:

  • Primary motor cortex for face and arm, and axons originating in the leg as well as face and arm areas that are headed for the internal capsule as part of the corticobulbar or corticospinal tracts
  • Broca's area and other related grey and white matter important for language expression, in the language-dominant (usually left) hemisphere
  • Frontal eye fields (important for 'looking at' eye movements to the opposite side)
  • The primary somatosensory cortex for the face and arm
  • Parts of the lateral frontal and parietal lobes are important for 3-D visuospatial perceptions of one's own body and of the outside world, and for the ability to interpret and express emotions in the nondominant (usually right) hemisphere

Explanation of Other Options:

Inferior cortical division of MCA (Option C): Supplies the lateral temporal lobe and orbital part of the inferior frontal gyrus; does not supply Broca's area.

ACA (Option B): Supplies the medial surfaces of the frontal lobes; not the lateral aspect where Broca's area is located.

Superior Cerebellar Artery (Option D): Supplies the cerebellum and parts of the brainstem; does not supply any part of the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was admitted to the hospital after suffering from a stroke. He later succumbed. The dark shaded area represents a lesion resulting from an embolus in which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dark shaded area in the cross-section of the lower pons indicates a lesion caused by an embolus. The paramedian branch of the basilar artery supplies blood to this area. Therefore, the correct answer is the Paramedian branch of the basilar artery.

An infarct in this area leads to medial pontine syndrome, as indicated by the shaded lesion.

  • Supplied Region: Medial part of the lower pons
  • Syndrome: Medial Pontine Syndrome (Foville's Syndrome)
  • Involved Artery: Paramedian branches of the basilar artery

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior cerebral artery (Option A): Supplies medial parts of frontal and parietal lobes; not the pons.

Middle cerebral artery (Option B): Supplies the lateral cerebral hemisphere; not the brainstem.

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (Option C): Supplies dorsolateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; involved in lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome.

choices.text: Perforating arteries associated with the Circle of Willis

questions.text: An infarct involving the hypothalamus would most likely result from occlusion of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hypothalamus, a crucial part of the brain, receives its blood supply from the perforating arteries associated with the Circle of Willis.

  • Primary Supply: Small central branches from the circulus arteriosus (Circle of Willis)
  • Source Arteries: Include anterior cerebral, anterior communicating, posterior communicating, and posterior cerebral arteries
  • If there is an occlusion or blockage in these arteries, it can lead to insufficient blood flow, causing an infarct (tissue damage) in the hypothalamus.
  • This can result in various neurological and endocrine disturbances, affecting vital functions regulated by the hypothalamus, such as temperature regulation, hormone secretion, and control of appetite and sleep.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior spinal artery (Option A): Supplies anterior spinal cord and medulla; not involved in hypothalamic circulation.

Vertebral artery (Option B): Gives rise to basilar artery and PICA; does not directly supply the hypothalamus.

Anterior cerebral artery (Option C): Supplies medial frontal lobe and lamina terminalis; contributes partially, but not the major supply.

questions.text: A neurological examination of a 51-year-old woman revealed loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of her body, decreased sense of taste on the left side, and hoarseness of voice. She also complained of dizziness and nausea. Which of the following arteries is most likely occluded?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms described in the question suggest a lesion in the brainstem, specifically affecting the lateral medulla.

  • This is known as Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome.
  • The PICA supplies the lateral medulla, and its occlusion can result in the symptoms described, including loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body, decreased taste sensation on the same side of the tongue, hoarseness, dizziness, and nausea.
  • Therefore, the occlusion of the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option A): Supplies occipital lobe, inferomedial temporal lobe, and thalamus. Its infarction causes visual field defects and thalamic sensory syndrome, not cranial nerve-related symptoms.

Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA) (Option B): Supplies lateral inferior pons, not the medulla. Its infarction causes lateral pontine syndrome, which involves facial paralysis (CN VII) and loss of lacrimation, not hoarseness or loss of taste.

Anterior Spinal Artery (Option D): Supplies anterior 2/3 of spinal cord and medial medulla. Infarction here causes medial medullary syndrome, not lateral symptoms. e.g., contralateral hemiparesis, medial lemniscus signs, and CN XII palsy.

choices.text: Motor and sensory function in the right lower limb
Motor and sensory function in the left lower limb
Motor and sensory function in the right upper limb
Motor and sensory function in the left upper limb

questions.text: As a resident physician, you are viewing an angiogram, which illustrates the occlusion of the Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) supplying the right cerebral hemisphere. Based on this finding, the patient is most likely to have a deficit in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Occlusion of the right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) affects the contralateral (left-sided) motor and sensory areas responsible for the lower limb.

  • The ACA supplies the medial aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes, including the paracentral lobule (primary motor and sensory cortex for the lower limb).
  • Because motor and sensory pathways decussate (cross over), a right ACA infarct will affect the left lower limb.
  • This results in contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss involving mainly the leg and foot.

Explanation of Other Options:

Motor and sensory function in the right lower limb (Option A): This would result from left ACA occlusion, not right ACA.

Motor and sensory function in the right upper limb (Option C): The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral convexity, where the upper limb is represented.

Motor and sensory function in the left upper limb (Option D): Again, MCA territory; unrelated to ACA occlusion.

questions.text: An occlusion of which artery would result in a loss of voluntary motor function and an oculomotor nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior communicating artery (PCoA) lies in close proximity to the oculomotor nerve. An aneurysm or pathology involving this artery can compress the nerve, resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy.

  • Oculomotor palsy manifests as ptosis, pupillary dilation, and eye deviated down and out.
  • Compression due to a PCoA aneurysm is one of the most common vascular causes of isolated third nerve palsy.
  • Voluntary motor impairment may occur secondary to mass effect on adjacent midbrain structures, but is not due to PCoA occlusion directly impairing cortical motor pathways.

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) (Option A): Supplies the lateral medulla; occlusion leads to Wallenberg syndrome. It does not affect the oculomotor nerve or voluntary motor cortex.

Middle cerebral artery (Option C): Supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere (face/upper limb area); not related to the oculomotor nerve.

Posterior cerebral artery (Option D): Supplies the occipital lobe and midbrain structures; can rarely affect the oculomotor nerve, but PCoA aneurysm is more classically associated with isolated oculomotor nerve palsy.

choices.text: Anterior Cerebral Artery - Deficits to the left lower limb
Anterior Cerebral Artery - Deficits to the right lower limb
Middle Cerebral Artery - Deficits to the right upper limb
Middle Cerebral Artery - Deficits to the left upper limb

questions.text:
A patient has a severe stroke in the artery marked in the below angiogram. As a physician, you know.
(i) the name of the artery and
(ii) the region of the body that will present with motor and somatosensory deficits. Identify the correct answer.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere, including motor and sensory cortices representing the upper limb and face. A lesion in the left MCA leads to deficits on the right upper limb and face.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior Cerebral Artery - Deficits to left lower limb (Option A): ACA supplies medial surface of cerebral hemisphere; left ACA infarct → right lower limb weakness.

Anterior Cerebral Artery - Deficits to right lower limb (Option B): Would occur in left ACA infarct; incorrect hemisphere-limb mapping here.

Middle Cerebral Artery - Deficits to left upper limb (Option D): Would result from right MCA infarct; incorrect side given.

choices.text: A stroke in the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)
A stroke in the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)
A stroke in the right superior cerebellar artery
A stroke in the left superior cerebellar artery

questions.text: A 49-year-old man keeps complaining of a loss of taste, a loss of pain and temperature on the left side below his neck, hoarseness of voice, and slight ataxia. You believe that which of the following has occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms described in the question, blood obstruction and temperature on the left side below the neck, hoarseness of voice, and slight ataxia, are consistent with a stroke in the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

  • The PICA supplies blood to the lateral medulla, which controls functions such as taste, pain and temperature sensation, and coordination of movement. Therefore, a stroke in this artery would result in the observed symptoms on the left side of the body.

The following nuclei and tracts are involved:

  • Nucleus ambiguus → hoarseness, dysphagia
  • Spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract → ipsilateral loss of pain & temperature from face
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract → contralateral loss of pain & temperature from the body
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle → ipsilateral ataxia
  • Nucleus of solitary tract → loss of taste (dysgeusia)

Explanation of Other Options:

A stroke in the left PICA (Option B): Would cause similar findings on the opposite (left) side; symptoms here are right-sided.

A stroke in the right superior cerebellar artery (Option C): Causes cerebellar ataxia but does not produce features like hoarseness or facial pain/temp loss.

A stroke in the left superior cerebellar artery (Option D): Wrong side and wrong vascular territory.
